headline: Big Lie 2.0: White supremacy has no place in the Republican Party
author: EJ Montini
sentences:
Rogers called heroic Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who is standing firm against Russian aggression, “a globalist puppet for Soros and the Clintons.”
Rogers also expressed love and support for conference organizer Nick Fuentes, who called the United States “the evil empire of the world” and who added, “Now, they’re going and saying, ‘Vladimir Putin is Adolf Hitler,’ as if that isn’t a good thing.”
The Arizona Senate on Tuesday voted overwhelmingly to censure Rogers.

If supremacists are still in the party ...
Republican Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, in condemning Arizona’s Rep. Paul Gosar and Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene for participating in the America First conference, a haven for racists, white supremacists, anti-Semites and supporters of Russia’s Vladimir Putin, said on Monday that “there’s no place in the Republican Party for white supremacists or antisemitism.”
That, sadly, is a lie.

Republican Rep. Adam Kinzinger – who has been attacked by fellow Republicans, along with Rep. Liz Cheney, for participating in the committee investigating the Jan. 6 insurrection – said about Gosar and Greene, “What I think we should do is kick them out of the party.

It's no better in Arizona with Wendy Rogers
Here in Arizona, the hate speech is put on what amounts to daily – even hourly – display by Republican state Sen. Wendy Rogers, who also hung out with the racists and the anti-Semites at the America First conference.

Likewise, Ronna McDaniel, chair of the Republican National Committee, issued a statement saying “white supremacy, neo-Nazism, hate speech and bigotry” are “disgusting” and said they would have “no home in the Republican Party.”
Again, not true.
So, when the leaders of the Republican Party, both in Arizona and nationally say that “white supremacy, neo-Nazism, hate speech and bigotry” have no place in the Republican Party, don't believe them.
Arizona judge rules that 'law enforcement' is NOT a profession If the Constitution means anything, kick Rep. Gosar off the ballot Does Ducey really think cops in Alaska can help secure our border?
All of those things – white supremacy, neo-Nazism, hate speech and bigotry – have found a most comfortable home with some Republicans.
And the ugly truth is that “white supremacy, neo-Nazism, hate speech and bigotry” actually DO have a home in the Republican Party.
Opinion: Republicans condemn hate speech, bigotry and antisemitism, but those who preach it remain in office and in the GOP.
There most definitely IS a place in the GOP those who hold such beliefs, or they would not have been elected to office.

Liz and I can get censured, they’re going to get help up as the future leaders of the party.”
Exactly.
Censure is a way politicians pretend to take action against a wayward colleague.
It was a symbolic gesture that, again, means nothing.
Neither does condemnation without punitive action.
Reach Montini at ed.montini@arizonarepublic.com.
For more opinions content, please subscribe.
Are they outcasts or future party leaders?
Is Rogers still in the Republican Party?
Let’s call that what it is: Big Lie 2.0.
Is she still in the Arizona Legislature?
Is Gosar still in the Republican Party?
And they would not remain in the party.
What do I think we’re going to do?
Is he still a member of Congress?
Condemnation means nothing.
Or reelected, like Gosar.
A lot of them, actually.
Censure means nothing.
It’s all for looks.
Censure is a joke.
It means nothing.
Not these days.
Nothing.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
